newsitem.title: FRENCH GUIANA: Guiana independence leaders charged with arson.
newsitem.headline: Guiana independence leaders charged with arson.

text.p: Four more people, including three leading members of French Guiana's independence movement, have been charged with arson following their detention and transfer to the French Caribbean island of Martinique, state-owned television said on Saturday.

The television report -- citing French judicial sources -- said Jean-Victor Castor and Fabien Canavy, both members of the Guiana Workers Union (UTG), and Jean-Claude Ringuet, a member of the Guiana National Popular Party (PNPG), were among those charged with setting fire to the home of French Guiana's state prosecutor, Jean-Luc Beck, during riots last November.
Both the UTG and PNPG favour French Guiana's independence from France.

Ten people, including Alain Michel, a founding member of the PNPG, have been charged and sent to Martinique this month for the attack on Beck's home. It occurred during a first wave of riots that shook the French overseas department on the northeast coast of South America during four days last November.
The arrests triggered riots in Cayenne during three nights in the last 10 days. The most violent incidents occurred last Thursday and left nine police wounded, including eight by gunfire.
Paramilitary riot police flown in from mainland France clashed with hooded and armed demonstrators in the town's centre.
Police fired tear gas to disperse crowds. Rioters fired hunting rifles and threw Molotov cocktail firebombs. Looters ransacked stores. Those owned by ethnic Chinese were hardest hit, witnesses said.
Officials said a total of 11 police have been injured during the three nights. One civilian bystander lost an eye when a tear gas grenade exploded in his face.

The alleged arsonists were arrested in French Guiana's capital of Cayenne on Tuesday and taken to Martinique aboard a French naval vessel. Their transfer to Martinique was to enable an independent public prosecutor to handle the cases.
French officials described those riots as "a deliberate attempt to destabilise French Guiana."

French Guiana is the only non-independent territory on the mainland of the Western Hemisphere. Its economy is heavily dependent on subsidies from France and 23 percent of the population of 150,000 is unemployed.
Officials on Friday played down the rioting. Dominique Vian, French government representative (Prefect), told a news conference that the violence did not constitute an insurrection.
"The situation is not an insurrection, we are far from that," Vian said.
